article.paragraph: Comet HaleBopp(Astronomical naming conventions#Cometsformally designatedC/1995 O1) was perhaps the most widely observedcometof the 20th century and one of the brightest seen for many decades. It was visible to the naked eye for a record 18 months, twice as long as the previous record holder, theGreat Comet of 1811.

HaleBopp was discovered on July 23, 1995, at a great distance from theSun, raising expectations that the comet would brighten considerably by the time it passed close to Earth. Although predicting the brightness of comets with any degree of accuracy is very difficult, HaleBopp met or exceeded most predictions when it passedperihelionon April 1, 1997. The comet was dubbed theGreat cometGreat Cometof 1997.
article.heading: Discovery
article.paragraph: The comet was discovered independently on July 23, 1995 by two observers,Alan Hale (astronomer)Alan HaleandThomas Bopp, both in theUnited States.cite journalThe comets of 1995ShanklinJonathan D.Journal of the British Astronomical Association200011063112000JBAA..110..311S

Hale had spent many hundreds of hours searching for comets without success, and was tracking known comets from his driveway inNew Mexicowhen he chanced upon HaleBopp just after midnight. The comet had anapparent magnitudeof 10.5 and lay near theglobular cluster M70in the constellation ofSagittarius (constellation)Sagittarius.Hale first established that there was no otherdeep-sky objectnear M70, and then consulted a directory of known comets, finding that none were known to be in this area of the sky. Once he had established that the object was moving relative to the background stars, heemailedtheCentral Bureau for Astronomical Telegrams, the clearing house for astronomical discoveries.cite newsComet of the decade Part IIhttp://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,986055,00.htmlTimeMarch 17, 1997Michael D.Lemonick2008-10-30

Bopp did not own atelescope. He was out with friends nearStanfield, Arizonaobserving star clusters andgalaxygalaxieswhen he chanced across the comet while at the eyepiece of his friend's telescope. He realized he might have spotted something new when, like Hale, he checked his star maps to determine if any other deep-sky objects were known to be near M70, and found that there were none. He alerted the Central Bureau for Astronomical Telegrams through aWestern Uniontelegram.Brian G. Marsden, who had run the bureau since 1968, laughed, "Nobody sends telegrams anymore. I mean, by the time that telegram got here, Alan Hale had already e-mailed us three times with updated coordinates."cite webhttp://science.nationalgeographic.com/science/space/solar-system/comets-age.htmlThe Age of CometsWilliamDecember 1997Newcott[[National Geographic Society]]7 December 2009"Nobody sends telegrams anymore..."

The following morning, it was confirmed that this was a new comet, and it was given the designation C/1995 O1. The discovery was announced inInternational Astronomical Unioncircular 6187.cite webHaleA.Bopp, T.Stevens, J.IAU Circular No. 6187[[International Astronomical Union|IAU]]July 23, 1995http://www.cbat.eps.harvard.edu/iauc/06100/06187.html#Item12011-07-05cite journalAmateur Contributions in the study of Comet Hale–BoppEarth, Moon, and Planets791–31997307–308ThomasBopp10.1023/A:10062620063641997EM&P...79..307B

The comet may have been observed by ancient Egyptians during the reign of pharaohPepi I(23322283 BC). In Pepi's pyramid inSaqqarais a text referring to an "nhh-star" as a companion of the pharaoh in the heavens, where "langegynhh" is the hieroglyph for long hair."The Lost Tomb",Kent Weeks, ISBN 0-297-81847-3, page 198
article.heading: Early observation
article.paragraph: HaleBopp's orbital position was calculated as 7.2 astronomical units(AU) from the Sun, placing it betweenJupiterandSaturnand by far the greatest distance from Earth at which a comet had been discovered by amateurs.cite journalComet C/1995 O1 (Hale-Bopp)http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/mpec/J95/J95P01.htmlMarsdenB. G.Brian G. Marsden1995Minor Planet Electronic Circular1995-P05cite journalEvolution of a Spiral Jet in the Inner Coma of Comet Hale-Bopp (1995 O1)M. R.Kidger10.1086/310008The Astrophysical Journal Letters19964612L119–L122Serra-RicartMiquelBellot-RubioLuis R.CasasRicard1996ApJ...461L.119KMost comets at this distance are extremely faint, and show no discernible activity, but HaleBopp already had an observablecoma (cometary)coma.An image taken at theAnglo-Australian Telescopein 1993 was found to show the then-unnoticed comet some 13 AU from the Sun,cite webMcNaughtR. H.West, R. M.Circular No. 6198http://www.cbat.eps.harvard.edu/iauc/06100/06198.html[[International Astronomical Union|IAU]]August 2, 19952011-07-05a distance at which most comets are essentially unobservable. (Comet HalleyHalley's Cometwas more than 100 times fainter at the same distance from the Sun.)cite journalBiverN.Substantial outgassing of CO from Comet Hale–Bopp at large heliocentric distancehttp://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v380/n6570/abs/380137a0.htmlNature380137–139199610.1038/380137a086003856570RauerHDespoisDMorenoRPaubertGBockelée-MorvanDColomPCrovisierJGérardEJordaLaurent1996Natur.380..137B8Analysis indicated later that itscomet nucleuswas 6020 kilometres in diameter, approximately six times the size ofHalley's CometHalley.

Its great distance and surprising activity indicated that comet HaleBopp might become very bright indeed when it reachedperihelionin 1997. However, comet scientists were wary comets can be extremely unpredictable, and many have large outbursts at great distance only to diminish in brightness later.Comet Kohoutekin 1973 had been touted as a 'comet of the century' and turned out to be unspectacular.
article.heading: Perihelion
article.paragraph: File:Comet-Hale-Bopp-29-03-1997 hires adj.jpgthumbright150pxThe comet became a spectacular sight in early 1997.HaleBopp became visible to thenaked eyein May 1996, and although its rate of brightening slowed considerably during the latter half of that year,scientists were still cautiously optimistic that it would become very bright. It was too closely aligned with the Sun to be observable during December 1996, but when it reappeared in January 1997 it was already bright enough to be seen by anyone who looked for it, even from large cities withlight pollutionlight-pollutedskies.cite newsComet Holds Clues to Birth of Timehttp://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?resBrowneMalcolm R.March 9, 1997The New York Times

TheInternetwas a growing phenomenon at the time, and numerous websites that tracked the comet's progress and provided daily images from around the world became extremely popular. The Internet played a large role in encouraging the unprecedented public interest in comet HaleBopp.cite webThe Trail of Hale-Bopphttp://www.sciam.com/article.cfm?idScientific American1997-03-172008-10-23

As the comet approached the Sun, it continued to brighten, shining at 2nd magnitude in February, and showing a growing pair ofComet tailtails, the blue gas tail pointing straight away from the Sun and the yellowish dust tail curving away along its orbit. On March 9, aSolar eclipse of March 9, 1997solar eclipseinChina,Mongoliaand easternSiberiaallowed observers there to see the comet in the daytime.cite journalThe total solar eclipse of 1997 March 9McGeeH. W.Journal of the British Astronomical Association19971073112–1131997JBAA..107..112MPoitevinP.HaleBopp had its closest approach to Earth on March 22, 1997 at a distance of 1.315 astronomical unitAU.cite webhttp://stardust.jpl.nasa.gov/science/hb.htmlComet Hale-Bopp2008-10-09StardustJet Propulsion Laboratory, NASANovember 26, 2003

As it passed perihelion on April 1, 1997 the comet developed into a spectacular sight. It shone brighter than any star in the sky exceptSirius, and its dust tail stretched 4045degree (angle)degreesacross the sky.cite webhttp://www.eso.org/public//events/astro-evt/hale-bopp/comet-hale-bopp-summary-apr13-97-rw.htmlComet Hale-Bopp (April 13, 1997)2008-11-23WestRichard M.Richard Martin WestApril 13, 1997European Southern Observatorycite journalB. S.ShylajaBulletin of the Astronomical Society of India25155–1561997What's New With Hale Bopp?1997BASI...25..155SThe comet was visible well before the sky got fully dark each night, and while many great comets are very close to the Sun as they pass perihelion, comet HaleBopp was visible all night tonorthern hemisphereobservers.cite webhttp://www.eso.org/public//events/astro-evt/hale-bopp/comet-hale-bopp-summary-mar07-97-rw.htmlComet Hale-Bopp (March 7, 1997)2008-11-25WestRichard M.Richard Martin WestMarch 7, 1997European Southern Observatory
article.heading: After perihelion
article.paragraph: After its perihelion passage, the comet moved into the southern celestial hemisphere. The comet was much less impressive tosouthern hemisphereobservers than it had been in the northern hemisphere, but southerners were able to see the comet gradually fade from view during the second half of 1997. The last naked-eye observations were reported in December 1997, which meant that the comet had remained visible without aid for 569 days, or about 18 and a half months.cite journalKidgerM.R.2004Earth, Moon, and Planets781–3169–177The Visual Light Curve Of C/1995 O1 (Hale-Bopp) From Discovery To Late 1997http://www.springerlink.com/content/h72381014307x661/10.1023/A:1006228113533HurstG.JamesN.1997EM&P...78..169KThe previous record had been set by theGreat Comet of 1811, which was visible to the naked eye for about 9 months.

The comet continued to fade as it receded, but is still being tracked by astronomers. In October 2007, 10 years after the perihelion and at distance of 25.7Astronomical unitAUfrom Sun, the comet was still active as indicated by the detection of the CO-driven coma.cite journalSzabóGy. L.Frozen to death? -- Detection of comet Hale-Bopp at 30.7 AUEarth and Planetary Astrophysics11044351201110.1051/0004-6361/2011167931104.43512011A&A...531A..11Sand on August 7, 2012 at a 33.2 AU distance from the Sun.cite webAug 7, 2012 Comet Hale-Bopp C/1995 O1 - observed tonite Yahoo Groups Dave Herald http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/comets-ml/message/19755 2012-08-09Astronomers expect that the comet will remain observable with large telescopes until perhaps 2020, by which time it will be nearing 30th apparent magnitudemagnitude. By this time it will become very difficult to distinguish the comet from the large numbers of distant galaxies of similar brightness.cite webhttps://www.eso.org/public//events/astro-evt/hale-bopp/comet-hale-bopp-summary-feb07-97-rw.htmlComet Hale-Bopp (February 7, 1997)12 January 2015WestRichard M.Richard Martin WestFebruary 7, 1997European Southern Observatory
article.heading: Orbital changes
article.paragraph: File:Hale-Bopp orbit.svgthumb300pxrightHaleBopp at perihelion on April 1, 1997The comet likely made its previousperihelion4,200 years ago.cite web1997-04-10 Comet Hale-Bopp Orbit and Ephemeris Information JPL/NASA Yeomans, Don http://www2.jpl.nasa.gov/comet/ephemjpl8.html 2008-10-23Its orbit is almostperpendicularto the plane of theecliptic, which ensures that close approaches to planets are rare. However, in April 1996 the comet passed within 0.77 AU ofJupiter, close enough for its orbit to be affected by the planet'sgravity.The comet's orbit was shortened considerably to a period of roughly 2,533 years,and it will next return to the innerSolar Systemaround the year 4385.Its greatest distance from the Sun (aphelion) will be about 370 AU,reduced from about 525 AU.cite journalOrbit Determination and Evolution of Comet C/1995 O1 (Hale-Bopp)1997EM&P...79....3MMarsdenB. G.Brian G. MarsdenEarth, Moon, and Planets7913–15199710.1023/A:1006268813208cite web2005-12-23Comet Fact SheetNASA (National Space Science Data Center)Williams, David R.http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/planetary/factsheet/cometfact.html2008-12-05(pre-Perturbation (astronomy)perturbationorbit: semi-major axis 250AU; period 4000yr)

Over many orbits, the cumulative effect of gravitational perturbations on comets with high orbitalinclinationsand small perihelion distances is generally to reduce the perihelion distance to very small values. HaleBopp has about a 15% chance of eventually becoming asungrazing cometthrough this process.cite journalOrbit Determination and Evolution of Comet C/1995 O1 (Hale-Bopp)1996MNRAS.281..916BBaileyM. E.[[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society]]2811916–9241996Emel'YanenkoV. V.HahnG.HarrisN. W.HughesK. A.MuinonenK.ScottiJ. V.10.1093/mnras/281.3.916

It has been calculated that the previous visit by HaleBopp occurred in July 2215 BC.The comet may have presented a similar sight to people then, as the estimated closest approach to Earth was 1.4 AU, but no records of it have survived. HaleBopp may have had a near collision with Jupiter in early June 2215 BC, which probably caused a dramatic change in its orbit, and 2215 BC may have been its first passage through the inner Solar System.

The estimated probability of impactingEarthin future passages through the inner Solar System is remote, about 2.5109per orbit.Cite journalWeissmanPaul R. 2007 The cometary impactor flux at the Earth Proceedings of the International Astronomical Union 2S236441–450 [[Cambridge University Press]] 10.1017/S1743921307003559 978-0-521-86345-2 However, given that the comet nucleus is around 60 km in diameter,the consequences of such an impact would be apocalyptic. A calculation given by Weissmanconservatively estimates the diameter at 35 km; an estimated density of 0.6 g/cm3then gives a cometary mass of 1.31019g. An impact velocity of 52.5 km/s yields an impact energy of 1.91032ergs, or 4.4109TNT equivalentmegatons, about 44 times the estimated energy of theAlvarez hypothesisK-T impact event.
article.heading: Scientific results
article.paragraph: Comet HaleBopp was observed intensively byastronomyastronomersduring its perihelion passage, and several important advances in cometary science resulted from these observations. The dust production rate of the comet was very high (up to 2.0e6kg/s),cite journalParticulate Mass Loss from Comet Hale-Bopp1999AJ....117.1056JThe Astronomical Journal11721056–1062JewittDavid199910.1086/300743MatthewsHenrywhich may have made the inner comaOptical thicknessoptically thick.cite journalFernándezYanga R.The Inner Coma and Nucleus of Comet Hale–Bopp: Results from a Stellar Occultation1999Icar..140..205F1999Icarus1401205–22010.1006/icar.1999.6127WellnitzDennis D.BuieMarc W.DunhamEdward W.MillisRobert L.NyeRalph A.StansberryJohn A.WassermanLawrence H.a'HearnMichael F.LisseCarey M.GoldenMeg E.PersonMichael J.HowellRobert R.MarcialisRobert L.SpitaleJoseph N.Based on the properties of the dust grainshigh temperature, highalbedoand strong 10 m silicate emission featurethe astronomers concluded the dust grains are smaller than observed in any other comet.cite journalObservations of Unusually Small Dust Grains in the Coma of Comet Hale-Bopp C/1995 O12001ApJ...549..635MMasonC. G.The Astrophysical Journal20015491635–64610.1086/319039GehrzR. D.JonesT. J.WoodwardC E.HannerM. S.WilliamsD. M.

HaleBopp showed the highest ever linear polarization detected for any comet. Such polarization is the result of solar radiation getting scattered by the dust particles in the coma of the comet and depends on the nature of the grains. It further confirms that the dust grains in the coma of comet HaleBopp were smaller than inferred in any other comet.cite journalPolarimetric observations of the comet Hale-Bopp1998A&AS..129..489GGaneshS.Astronomy and Astrophysics Supplement19981295489–49310.1051/aas:1998201JoshiU. C.BaliyanK. S.DeshpandeM. R.
article.heading: Sodium tail
article.paragraph: File:Hale-Bopp sodium tail.gifthumbright150pxComet HaleBopp's neutral sodium tail (the straight tail extending up to the left from the nucleus)One of the most remarkable discoveries was that the comet had a third type of tail. In addition to the well-known gas and dust tails, HaleBopp also exhibited a faintsodiumtail, only visible with powerful instruments with dedicated filters. Sodium emission had been previously observed in other comets, but had not been shown to come from a tail. HaleBopp's sodium tail consisted ofelectric chargeneutral atoms(notions), and extended to some 50 million kilometres in length.cite journalThe Astrophysical Journal Letters4902L199–L202199710.1086/311040Neutral Sodium from Comet Hale–Bopp: A Third Type of TailCremonese, GBoehnhardt, HCrovisier, JRauer, HFitzsimmons, AFulle, MLicandro, JPollacco, DTozzi, G. P1997ApJ...490L.199Castro-ph/97100228WestR. M.

The source of the sodium appeared to be the innercoma (cometary)coma, although not necessarily thecomet nucleusnucleus. There are several possible mechanisms for generating a source of sodium atoms, including collisions between dust grains surrounding the nucleus, and 'sputtering' of sodium from dust grains byultravioletlight. It is not yet established which mechanism is primarily responsible for creating HaleBopp's sodium tail, and the narrowand diffusecite journalWilsonJ. K.Three tails of comet Hale-Bopp1998GeoRL..25..225WGeophysical Research Letters253225–22810.1029/97GL037041998BaumgardnerJ.MendilloM.components of the tail may have different origins.cite journalG.CremoneseSodium In Comets1997EM&P...79..209CEarth, Moon, and Planets791209–220199710.1023/A:1006245619568FulleMarco

While the comet's dust tail roughly followed the path of the comet's orbit and the gas tail pointed almost directly away from the Sun, the sodium tail appeared to lie between the two. This implies that the sodium atoms are driven away from the comet's head byradiation pressure.
article.heading: Deuterium abundance
article.paragraph: The abundance ofdeuteriumin comet HaleBopp in the form ofheavy waterwas found to be about twice that of Earth'soceans. If HaleBopp's deuterium abundance is typical of all comets, this implies that although cometary impacts are thought to be the source of a significant amount of theOrigin of water on Earthwater on Earth, they cannot be the only source.cite journalCometary DeuteriumSpace Science Reviews901–2199910.1023/A:100526920831033–43RolandMeierOwenTobias C.1999SSRv...90...33M

Deuterium was also detected in many otherhydrogencompounds in the comet. The ratio of deuterium to normal hydrogen was found to vary from compound to compound, which astronomers believe suggests that cometary ices were formed ininterstellar clouds, rather than in thesolar nebula. Theoretical modelling of ice formation in interstellar clouds suggests that comet HaleBopp formed at temperatures of around 2545 Kelvin.
article.heading: Organics
article.paragraph: Spectroscopic observations of HaleBopp revealed the presence of manyorganic chemistryorganic chemicals, several of which had never been detected in comets before. These complex molecules may exist within the cometary nucleus, or might be synthesised by reactions in the comet.cite journalOrganic synthesis in the coma of Comet Hale–Bopp?Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society3204200210.1046/j.1365-8711.2001.04208.xL61–L64S. D.RodgersCharnleyS. B.2001MNRAS.320L..61R
article.heading: Detection of argon
article.paragraph: HaleBopp was the first comet where thenoble gasargonwas detected.Noble gases are chemically inert and highlyVolatility (chemistry)volatile, and since different noble elements have different sublimation temperatures, they can be used for probing the temperature histories of the cometary ices.Kryptonhas a sublimation temperature of 1620 K and was found to be depleted more than 25 times relative to the solar abundance,cite journalDetection of Soft X-rays and a Sensitive Search for Noble Gases in Comet Hale-Bopp (C/1995 O1)1997Sci...277.1488KKrasnopolskyVladimir A.1997Science2771488–149110.1126/science.277.5331.148892785085331MummaMJAbbottMFlynnBCMeechKJYeomansDKFeldmanPDCosmoviciCBwhile argon with its higher sublimation temperature was enriched relative to the solar abundance.cite journalThe Discovery of Argon in Comet C/1995 O1 (Hale-Bopp)2000ApJ...544L.169SSternS. A.2000The Astrophysical Journal5442L169–L17210.1086/317312SlaterD. C.FestouM. C.ParkerJ. Wm.GladstoneG. R.A'hearnM. F.WilkinsonE.astro-ph/0011327Together these observations indicate that the interior of HaleBopp has always been colder than 3540 K, but has at some point been warmer than 20 K. Unless the solar nebula was much colder and richer in argon than generally believed, this suggests that the comet formed beyond Neptune in theKuiper beltregion and then migrated outward to theOort cloud.

article.paragraph: Comet HaleBopp's activity and outgassing were not spread uniformly over its nucleus, but instead came from several specific jets. Observations of the material streaming away from these jetscite webhttp://www2.jpl.nasa.gov/comet/anim30.htmlBergeron Comet Hale-Bopp Animation2008-10-14StardustJet Propulsion Laboratory, NASAallowed astronomers to measure the rotation period of the comet, which was found to be about 11 hours 46 minutes.cite journalAstronomy and Astrophysics Supplement Series1362245–256199910.1051/aas:1999213Dust continuum imaging of C/1995 O1 (Hale-Bopp): Rotation period and dust outflow velocityWarell, JLagerkvist, C.-ILagerros, J. S. V1999A&AS..136..245W
article.heading: Binary nucleus question
article.paragraph: In 1997 a paper was published that hypothesised the existence of a binarycomet nucleusnucleusto fully explain the observed pattern of comet HaleBopp's dust emission observed in October 1995. The paper was based on theoretical analysis, and did not claim an observational detection of the proposed satellite nucleus, but estimated that it would have a diameter of about 30 km, with the main nucleus being about 70 km across, and would orbit in about three days at a distance of about 180 km.cite journalDetection of a Satellite Orbiting The Nucleus of Comet Hale–Bopp (C/1995 O1)Earth, Moon, and Planets773199710.1023/A:1006230712665155–163Z.Sekanina1997EM&P...77..155SThis analysis was confirmed by observations in 1996 using Wide-Field Planetary Camera 2 of theHubble Space Telescopewhich had taken images of the comet that revealed the satellite.cite journalDetection of a Satellite orbiting the Nucleus of Comet Hale-Bopp (C/1995 O1) Proceedings of the First International Conference on Comet Hale-Bopp Sekanina Z. European Organisation for Astronomical Research in the Southern Hemisphere 1998

Although observations usingadaptive opticsin late 1997 and early 1998 showed a double peak in the brightness of the nucleus,cite journalMarchisF.Astronomy & Astrophysics1999Adaptive optics observations of the innermost coma of C/1995 O1. R.Le MignantD.controversy still exists over whether such observations can only be explained by a binary nucleus.The discovery of the satellite was not confirmed by other observations.cite journalMcCarthyD. W.Comet Hale–Bopp in outburst: Imaging the dynamics of icy particles with HST/NICMOS2007Icar..189..184M2007Icarus1891184–19510.1016/j.icarus.2007.01.019StolovySCampinsHLarsonSSamarasinhaNKernScite journalWeaverH. A.Post-Perihelion HST Observations of Comet Hale–Bopp (C/1995 O1)1999Icar..141....1W1999Icarus141110.1006/icar.1999.61591–12FeldmanP. D.a'HearnM. F.ArpignyC.BrandtJ. C.SternS. A.Also, while comets have been observed to break up before,cite journalSekaninaZ.The problem of split comets revisited1997A&A...318L...5SAstronomy and Astrophysics Letters1997318L5–L8no case has previously been found of a stable binary nucleus. Given the very small mass of this comet, the orbit of the binary nucleus would be easily disrupted by the gravity of the Sun andplanets.
article.heading: UFO claims
article.paragraph: In November 1996 amateur astronomer Chuck Shramek ofHouston, Texastook acharge-coupled deviceCCDimage of the comet, which showed a fuzzy, slightly elongated object nearby. When his computer sky-viewing program did not identify the star, Shramek called theArt Bellradio programCoast to Coast AMto announce that he had discovered a "Saturn-like object" following HaleBopp.unidentified flying objectUFOenthusiasts, such asremote viewingproponentCourtney Brown (researcher)Courtney Brown, soon concluded that there was anextraterrestrial lifealienspacecraftfollowing the comet.cite newsThe man who spread the mythhttp://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,986171,00.htmlTimeApril 14, 1997LeonJaroffWillwerth, James2008-10-30

Several astronomers, including Alan Hale,cite journalHale-Bopp Comet MadnessAlanHaleSkeptical Inquirer199721225–28http://www.csicop.org/si/show/hale-bopp_comet_madness/claimed the object was simply an 8.5-magnitudestar, SAO141894, which did not appear on Shramek's computer program because the user preferences were set incorrectly.cite bookGreat CometsRobertBurnhamLevy, David H.2000Cambridge University Press978-0-521-64600-0191Later, Art Bell even claimed to have obtained an image of the object from an anonymous astrophysicist who was about to confirm its discovery. However, astronomersOlivier HainautandDavid J. Tholenof theUniversity of Hawaiistated that the alleged photo was an altered copy of one of their own comet images.cite webJanuary 15, 1997Fraudulent use of a IfA/UH picturehttp://www.sc.eso.org/~ohainaut/Hale_Bopp/hb_ufo_tholen.htmlEuropean Organisation for Astronomical Research in the Southern Hemisphere2008-10-14David J.Tholenhttps://web.archive.org/web/20070930225155/http://www.sc.eso.org/~ohainaut/Hale_Bopp/hb_ufo_tholen.htmlSeptember 30, 2007

A few months later, in March 1997, 39 members of the cultHeaven's Gate (religious group)Heaven's Gatecommitted mass suicide with the intention of teleporting to a spaceship they believed was flying behind the comet.cite journalHeaven's Gate: The EndWendy GaleRobinsonJournal of Computer-Mediated Communication33http://jcmc.indiana.edu/vol3/issue3/robinson.html

Nancy Lieder, a self-proclaimedcontacteewho claims to receive messages from aliens through an implant in her brain, stated that HaleBopp was a fiction designed to distract the population from the coming arrival ofNibiru cataclysm"Nibiru"or "Planet X", a giant planet whose close passage would disrupt the Earth's rotation, causing global cataclysm.cite newsComets Breed Fear, Fascination and Web SitesGeorge Johnsonhttp://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/28/us/comets-breed-fear-fascination-and-web-sites.html?sec2009-09-27The New York Times1997-03-28Although Lieder's original date for the apocalypse, May 2003, passed without incident, predictions of the imminent arrival of Nibiru continued by various conspiracy websites, most of whom tied it to the2012 phenomenon.cite webThe Myth of Nibiru and the End of the World in 2012David MorrisonSkepical Enquirerhttp://www.csicop.org/si/2008-05/morrison.html2009-04-28
article.heading: Legacy
article.paragraph: File:ESO-Comet Hale-Bopp-Phot-07a-01-hires.jpgthumb150pxrightComet HaleBopp, at a distance of nearly 2 billion kilometres from the Sun. Credit:ESOItslengthy period of visibility and extensive coverage in the media meant that HaleBopp was probably the most-observed comet in history, making a far greater impact on the general public than the return ofComet HalleyHalley's Cometin 1986, and certainly seen by a greater number of people than witnessed any of Halley's previous appearances. For instance, 69% of Americans had seen HaleBopp by April 9, 1997.cite journalAguirreEdwin L.The Great Comet of 1997Sky and Telescopehttp://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/skyandtelescope/access/886291661.html?didsJuly 1997

HaleBopp was a record-breaking cometthe farthest comet from the Sun discovered by amateurs,with the largest well-measured cometary nucleus known after95P/Chiron,cite journalFernándezYanga R.The Nucleus of Comet Hale-Bopp (C/1995 O1): Size and Activityhttp://www.springerlink.com/content/pr2756540kx94403/2002Earth, Moon, and Planets8913–2510.1023/A:10215450314312000EM&P...89....3Fand it was visible to the naked eye for twice as long as the previous record-holder.It was also brighter than magnitude 0 for eight weeks, longer than any other recorded comet.
